summary: A company is a separate legal entity distinct from its members. Even a one-man company has a separate existence from its sole shareholder.

case_name: Tata Consultancy Services v. State of AP
summary: Computer software on medium is goods liable to sales tax.

case_name: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
summary: Parliament can amend the Constitution but cannot alter its basic structure. The basic structure includes supremacy of the Constitution, rule of law, separation of powers, and fundamental rights.
relevance: Most important constitutional law case in India

case_name: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
principle: Right to Life and Personal Liberty
summary: Article 21 does not merely guarantee the right against deprivation of life or personal liberty but also the right to live with dignity. Any procedure depriving a person of life or liberty must be just, fair, and reasonable.

The Supreme Court laid down guidelines to prevent sexual harassment of women at the workplace. These guidelines were binding until the enactment of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013.

case_name: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India
summary: Section 377 of IPC was struck down to the extent it criminalized consensual sexual conduct between adults. The court held it violated Articles 14, 15, 19, and 21 of the Constitution.

case_name: K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India
summary: Right to privacy is a fundamental right under Article 21 of the Constitution. It includes informational privacy, bodily autonomy, and the privacy of personal choices.
relevance: Foundation for data protection law in India

case_name: Shreya Singhal v. Union of India
summary: Section 66A of the IT Act was struck down as unconstitutional for being vague and overbroad, violating the right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a).
relevance: Key internet freedom and free speech case

case_name: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India
summary: An enterprise engaged in a hazardous or inherently dangerous activity owes an absolute duty to the community to ensure no harm. No exceptions or defences are available â€” stricter than the Rylands v. Fletcher rule.
relevance: Foundation of environmental law in India

case_name: S.R. Bommai v. Union of India
summary: The imposition of President's Rule under Article 356 is subject to judicial review. Secularism is a basic feature of the Constitution. The court restricted misuse of Article 356 by the central government.

case_name: Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation
summary: The right to livelihood is included in the right to life under Article 21. Pavement dwellers cannot be evicted without following due process of law and providing them a hearing.
relevance: Expanded Article 21 to include right to livelihood

case_name: Indian Young Lawyers Association v. State of Kerala
summary: The ban on entry of women aged 10-50 into Sabarimala temple was held to be violative of their fundamental rights under Articles 14, 15, 25, and 26 of the Constitution.

case_name: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar
summary: Police must not automatically arrest the accused in cases under Section 498A IPC. Magistrates must not mechanically authorize detention. Laid down specific guidelines to prevent misuse of arrest powers.

case_name: Lalita Kumari v. Government of UP
summary: Registration of FIR under Section 154 CrPC is mandatory if the information discloses commission of a cognizable offence. Police cannot refuse to register an FIR.
relevance: Ensures access to criminal justice system

case_name: Shayara Bano v. Union of India
summary: The practice of instant triple talaq (talaq-e-biddat) was declared unconstitutional. It violated the fundamental rights of Muslim women under Articles 14, 15, and 21.
relevance: Led to Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019
